Detailed Description

template<class T>
class mt::Singleton< T >

Singleton pattern.

If you want to make sure that only the singleton instance of <T> is created, and that users cannot create their own instances of <T>, do the following to class <T>:

  • Make the constructor of <T> private (or protected)
  • Make Singleton a friend of <T>

Here is an example: 

 class Foo {
   friend class mt::Singleton<Foo>;
 private:
   foo () { cout << "foo constructed" << endl; }
   ~foo () { cout << "foo destroyed" << endl; }
 };
 typedef mt::Singleton<Foo> FooSingleton;

Member Function Documentation

template<class T >
T * mt::Singleton< T >::instance (  )  [static]

Get instance.

The first call will create the object.

Returns:
Smart pointer to instance of the class.

Definition at line 57 of file Singleton.h.

template<class T >
void mt::Singleton< T >::release (  )  [static]

Release instance.

After call the method the pointer will be deleted and set to NULL.

Note: if after release() call instance() than second instance will be created.
